description: From Middle English bombard, from Middle French bombarde (“a bombard, mortar, catapult"; also "a bassoon-like musical instrument”), from Latin bombus (“buzzing; booming”).
The modern pronunciation is from modern French bombarde.

entries.meaning: a medieval primitive cannon, used chiefly in sieges for throwing heavy stone balls.
examples: They planted in divers places twelve great bombards, wherewith they threw huge stones into the air, which, falling down into the city, might break down the houses.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) a large liquor container made of leather, in the form of a jug or a bottle.

examples: With mines and parallels contracts the space; Then bids the battering floats his labors crown And pour their bombard on the shuddering town

description: From French bombarder, from Middle French bombarde (“a bombard”).

verbs.description: bombard (third-person singular simple present bombards, present participle bombarding, simple past and past participle bombarded)

entries.meaning: To continuously attack something with bombs, artillery shells or other missiles or projectiles.
examples: The enemy's stronghold was bombarded for 3 hours straight.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To attack something or someone by directing objects at them.
(figuratively) To continuously send or direct (at someone)
examples: I was bombarded with WhatsApp messages after appearing on the news.
Please don't bombard me with questions right now, I'll answer them at the end of the statement.

entries.meaning: (physics) To direct at a substance an intense stream of high-energy particles, usually sub-atomic or made of at most a few atoms.
